statement.text: Type 2 endoleak on CT angiography (CTA) appears as contrast enhancement within the aneurysm sac outside the stent-graft lumen on arterial phase imaging, with identifiable feeding and/or draining vessels separate from the attachment zones.
statement.formal: CTA Diagnosis: Contrast in perigraft space + Arterial phase timing + Identifiable branch vessels + Remote from attachment zones = Type 2 Endoleak

explanation.intuition: On a CT scan with contrast, you see the stent-graft (the metal framework) sitting inside the aorta with bright white contrast inside it (flowing blood). If you also see contrast (white areas) in the space between the graft and the old aneurysm wall, connected to small branch vessels, that's a Type 2 endoleak.
explanation.key_insight: The key to diagnosing Type 2 (versus Type 1) is seeing the contrast enhancement away from the attachment sites and being able to trace it to aortic branch vessels like lumbar arteries or the IMA. This requires carefully examining all phases of the CTA.
explanation.technical_details: Type 2 endoleaks may appear on arterial phase (immediate imaging) or may only become apparent on delayed phase imaging (90-180 seconds post-contrast) as collateral flow is slower than systemic flow. Multi-phase imaging improves detection sensitivity from ~80% to >95%.

type_2_specific_features.location: Within aneurysm sac, remote from attachment zones
type_2_specific_features.enhancement_pattern: May be focal or diffuse within sac
type_2_specific_features.temporal_pattern: May appear or intensify on delayed imaging
type_2_specific_features.volume: Variable, from small focus to extensive sac filling

distinguishing_from_type_1.type_1_location: Adjacent to proximal or distal attachment zones
distinguishing_from_type_1.type_1_timing: Present on arterial phase, high flow
distinguishing_from_type_1.type_2_location: Away from attachments, in sac body
distinguishing_from_type_1.type_2_timing: May only appear on delayed phase

source_vessel_identification.imaging_clue: Paired enhancing foci on posterior wall

key_measurements.method: Outer wall to outer wall, perpendicular to vessel axis
key_measurements.planes: Measure in all planes, use maximum

key_measurements.advantage: More sensitive than diameter for detecting change

key_measurements.method: Enhanced region within sac on delayed phase
key_measurements.clinical_value: Larger volume may predict need for intervention

critical_comparisons: Sac diameter change from immediate post-op
Change in endoleak volume if present

false_positives.distinguishing_feature: Peristalsis on cine imaging, different anatomy

MR_angiography.accuracy: Comparable to CTA for endoleak detection

sources.citation: Reporting standards for endovascular aortic aneurysm repair
CT imaging after endovascular aortic aneurysm repair

learning_objectives: Recognize the importance of delayed phase imaging
Identify source vessels for Type 2 endoleaks
clinical_pearls: No delayed phase = missing ~20% of Type 2 endoleaks
Location matters: near attachment = Type 1, in sac body = likely Type 2
Multiplanar reformats essential for source vessel ID
Sac size trend more important than endoleak presence
Always compare to baseline 1-month scan, not immediate post-op
